title: 3M to Stop Making, Discontinue Use of Forever Chemicals; Company says it has already reduced its use of PFAS, which accumulate and take a long time to break down
text:
3M estimates that its current annual sales of manufactured PFAS are about $1.3 billion. Over the course of exiting the business of manufacturing PFAS, 3M expects to incur pretax charges of about $1.3 billion to $2.3 billion, including a $700 million to $1 billion charge in the current quarter.

3M said it would stop making all fluoropolymers, fluorinated fluids, and PFAS-based additive products by the end of 2025. The St. Paul, Minn.-based maker of Scotch tape, Post-it Notes and more said it intends to fulfill current contractual obligations during the transition period.

The company also said it would stop using PFAS across its products by the end of 2025, noting that it has already reduced its use of the substances over the past three years.

The company cited accelerating regulatory focus on eliminating the chemicals and "changing stakeholder expectations" in making the decision.

"While PFAS can be safely made and used, we also see an opportunity to lead in a rapidly evolving external regulatory and business landscape to make the greatest impact for those we serve," 3M Chief Executive Mike Roman said.
